Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Algorithms and software for resolving intersection problems in computer aided design
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is that it allows users of Computer-Aided Design (CAD) systems to create product models that can be used directly in downstream applications. Current workflows require extensive manual repair of geometric models before they can be used for Computer-Aided Engineering/Manufacturing. Within the US automotive industry alone nearly $600M/year is spent in direct cost and lost productivity on mitigating CAD problems. Entire business units or job shops are employed to deal with this expensive problem by repairing or reworking gap-ridden geometric models. Commercializing the algorithm developed will result in improved productivity in the engineering design process, resulting in better products that are designed more quickly than is possible with current CAD technology.

This I-Corps project focuses on development and commercialization of a novel software algorithm that resolves a ubiquitous problem in the Computer-Aided Design (CAD) industry, the gaps that arise at the intersections of surfaces in CAD models. The majority of modern geometric modeling relies on parametric freeform surfaces built as complex combinations of much simpler geometric shapes. However, the intersection of freeform surfaces in CAD currently results in highly approximated, incomplete solutions. The approach developed here is based on a thorough understanding of the parametric space underlying the geometry of most modern CAD models. The algorithm classifies and segments the intersection curve in parametric space, then reconstructs the intersecting surfaces such that their boundaries are guaranteed to lie on the intersection curve to the tolerance set by the user of the CAD system. The approach solves the problem in a way that produces objects in the same form as that of the original models, making them available in the modeler's native software package.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Industries from product design to movie animation to game design rely significantly on computerized geometric models. The majority of modern geometric modeling is based on freeform surfaces built as complex combinations of much simpler geometric shapes. However, the necessary operation of computing the intersection of freeform surfaces in computer-aided design (CAD) systems currently results in approximated solutions, Designers dedicate significant time repairing the numerous flaws and defects in the resulting "leaky", gap-ridden models. This situation is considered to be one of the most important problems in the fields of computer-aided design, analysis, and manufacturing. Entire branches of industry are devoted to repairing or "healing" geometric models.

Our research team has developed patented technology that addresses the trim problem, making model surfaces "watertight". Our approach solves the problem in a way that produces objects in the same form as that of the original models so they can be conveniently edited using the designer's preferred CAD system. Our solution provides a mathematical solution that takes advantage of a thorough understand of the parametric space underlying the geometry of most modern CAD models.

For this I-Corps Team project, we interviewed over 200 users of CAD and related technology in order to understand how our technology can be used to address the problems they face in their daily workflows. The resulting data also helped us to focus on a particular market segment for commercializing the technology. Based on this project we are working to establish partnerships to transition the technology from an academic research result into a commercially viable product. The project also allowed us to create a business model to serve the 19 million CAD users worldwide.

Users of downstream applications that we interviewed acknowledge that the surface intersection problem reduces their productivity. This obstacle affects all downstream users and customers of any CAD modeling effort. Within the US automotive industry alone, studies have shown nearly $600M/year is spent in direct cost and lost productivity, just on mitigating these problems. Entire business units or job shops are employed to deal with this expensive problem by repairing or reworking gap-ridden geometric models. By using our Watertight CAD solution, users may automatically produce watertight surfaces in all designs, regardless of dimensional complexity, within the tolerances and accuracies of the native CAD software. We predict customers may eliminate up to 90% of today's in-process Design-Through-Analysis workflow experienced in the $8.2 billion/year CAD industry. The algorithm is the foundation of our technology platform, and we believe it is scalable across a myriad of product opportunities that have the potential to alter the workflow of engineers and designers that utilize CAD systems to design and manufacture products today.
